dimensions.name: Concept Clarity
dimensions.description: How clearly the teacher explains basic operators (arithmetic, logical, comparison) and their usage.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Provides simple definitions; demonstrates each operator with clear, relevant examples.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Gives vague or ambiguous explanations; mixes different operator types without clear separation.

dimensions.name: Delivery & Communication
dimensions.description: Voice clarity, pacing, energy, and engagement when presenting operator concepts.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Clear articulation, varied tone, appropriate speed, and occasional emphasis on key symbols.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Monotone delivery, too rapid or too slow, excessive filler words, or unclear pronunciation of symbols.

dimensions.name: Content Structure
dimensions.description: Logical flow of the lesson: introduction → operator categories → examples → common pitfalls → summary.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Starts with overview, groups operators logically, uses transitions, and ends with recap.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Random ordering, jumps between topics, omits summary or transitions.

dimensions.name: Student Engagement
dimensions.description: Interaction techniques to involve learners, such as asking questions, live coding, or quick quizzes on operators.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Poses check‑understanding questions, invites learners to predict outcomes, uses interactive exercises.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Pure lecture without pauses, no questions, no opportunities for practice.

dimensions.name: Accuracy
dimensions.description: Correctness of the operator definitions, syntax, and example results.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: All operator symbols, precedence rules, and example calculations are correct.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Incorrect truth tables, wrong precedence, mis‑typed symbols, or erroneous example outputs.
